<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=39,EFW="2186742",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=134368,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK116:[08ZCE1.08ZCE77601]DY77601A.;13',USER='DBEMBEN',CD='11-JUL-2008;04:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dy77601_1_39"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the third quarter of fiscal 2008, the holders of $16,355 of 2.875% convertible notes redeemed their notes for 880,000&nbsp;shares of our common stock. As a result of the
redemption, common stock increased $880 and capital surplus increased $15,284. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with the acquisition of Avborne, we assumed a $25,000 industrial revenue bond secured by maintenance hangars located at Miami International Airport. The industrial revenue
bond matures on August&nbsp;1, 2018 and has a variable interest rate. The interest rate at May&nbsp;31, 2008 was 1.68%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the third quarter of fiscal 2006, we acquired $50,645 aggregate principal amount of our 2.875% Convertible Senior Notes due 2024, or approximately 76% of the previously
outstanding principal amount, in exchange for an aggregate 2,724,000 newly issued shares of common stock plus $3,893 in cash, in privately negotiated transactions exempt from the registration
requirements under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended. The number of shares issued was equivalent to the number into which the notes were convertible under the original terms of the notes. We
recorded a $3,893 pre-tax loss on the exchange of the notes into stock in advance of the call date of the notes; this loss was comprised of interest that the note holders would otherwise
have been entitled to receive as well as an incentive payment for the exchange. As a result of these transactions, our long-term debt decreased by $50,645 and stockholders' equity
increased by $46,600. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
fiscal 2008, treasury stock increased $21,122 reflecting the purchase of treasury shares of $9,527 and the impact from the exercise of stock options of $11,595. During fiscal 2007
and 2006, treasury stock increased $10,149 and $19,167, respectively, principally reflecting the impact from the exercise of stock options. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Use of Estimates  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have made estimates and utilized certain assumptions relating to the reporting of assets and liabilities and the disclosures of contingent liabilities to
prepare these consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>New Accounting Standards  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2007, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS&nbsp;157) "Fair Value Measurements." SFAS&nbsp;157 establishes a framework for measuring fair
value in generally accepted accounting principles, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements. SFAS&nbsp;157 is effective for fiscal years beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2007 for
financial assets and liabilities, as well as for any other assets that are carried at fair value on a recurring basis in financial statements. In November 2007, the FASB provided a one year deferral
of the implementation of SFAS&nbsp;157 for other non-financial assets and liabilities. We continue to review the impact of SFAS&nbsp;157 on our financial statements, but do not expect
a material impact on our results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February 2007, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;159 (SFAS&nbsp;159), "The Fair Value Option for Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities&#151;Including an Amendment to FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;115." SFAS&nbsp;159 allows companies, at specified election dates, the option to measure certain financial assets and liabilities at fair value. The election, which is applied
on an instrument by instrument basis, is typically irrevocable once made. Subsequent unrealized gains and losses on items for which the fair value option has been elected are to be reported in
earnings. SFAS&nbsp;159 is effective for fiscal years beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2007. We </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=40,EFW="2186742",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=1002525,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK116:[08ZCE1.08ZCE77601]DY77601A.;13',USER='DBEMBEN',CD='11-JUL-2008;04:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dy77601_1_40"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>continue
to review the impact of SFAS&nbsp;159 on our financial statements, but do not expect a material impact on our results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December 2007, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;160 (SFAS&nbsp;160), "Noncontrolling Interests in Consolidated Financial Statements&#151;an Amendment of ARB&nbsp;51." This
statement amends ARB&nbsp;51 to establish accounting and reporting standards for the noncontrolling interest (minority interest) in a subsidiary and for the deconsolidation of a subsidiary. Upon its
adoption, effective for us as of June&nbsp;1, 2009, noncontrolling interests will be classified as equity in the Company's financial statements and income and comprehensive income attributed to the
noncontrolling interest will be included in the Company's income and comprehensive income. The provisions of this standard must be applied retrospectively upon adoption. We are currently evaluating
the impact of adopting SFAS&nbsp;160 on our results of operations and financial position. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December 2007, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;141 (revised 2007) (SFAS&nbsp;141(R)), "Business Combinations." SFAS&nbsp;141(R) establishes principles and requirements for how an
acquirer in a business combination recognizes and measures the assets acquired, liabilities assumed, and any noncontrolling interest in the acquiree. The provisions of SFAS&nbsp;141(R) are effective
for our business combinations occurring on or after June&nbsp;1, 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
March 2008, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;161 (SFAS&nbsp;161), "Disclosures about Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities." SFAS&nbsp;161 amends and expands the disclosure
requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;133, "Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities," and is effective for fiscal years beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2008. We do not expect the
adoption of SFAS&nbsp;161 will have a material impact on our results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May 2008, the FASB issued Staff Position FSP APB&nbsp;14-1 (FSP APB&nbsp;14-1), "Accounting for Convertible Debt Instruments That May Be Settled in Cash
upon Conversion (Including Partial Cash Settlement)." FSP APB&nbsp;14-1 requires companies that have issued convertible debt that may be settled wholly or partly in cash when converted,
to account for the debt and equity components separately. The value assigned to the bond liability is the estimated value of a similar bond without the conversion feature as of the issuance date. The
difference between the proceeds for the convertible debt and the amount reflected as a bond liability is recorded as additional paid-in-capital. Interest expense is recorded
using the issuer's comparable debt rate. FSP APB&nbsp;14-1 will be effective for us beginning June&nbsp;1, 2009 (fiscal 2010) and will require retrospective application. We continue to
review the impact of FSP APB&nbsp;14-1 on our financial statements, however, we are currently estimating, based on the outstanding convertible notes at May&nbsp;31, 2008, the implementation of FSP
APB 14-1 will result in a reduction of our convertible notes of approximately $95,000, an increase in capital surplus of approximately $62,000 and an increase in deferred taxes of
approximately $33,000. In addition, we expect the implementation of FSP APB&nbsp;14-1 will reduce our diluted earnings per share by $0.12 to $0.15 per share in fiscal 2010. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Reclassification  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain amounts in the prior years' consolidated financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the current year's presentation. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2. Financing Arrangements  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revolving Credit Facility  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On August&nbsp;31, 2007, we amended our credit agreement dated August&nbsp;31, 2006 (the "Credit Agreement") with various financial institutions, as lenders,
and LaSalle Bank National Association, as administrative agent for the lenders (the "Amendment"). The Amendment increased our unsecured revolving credit amount to $250,000 from $140,000. Under certain
circumstances, we may request an increase to the revolving commitment by an aggregate amount of up to $75,000, not to exceed $325,000 in total. The Amendment extended the term of our Credit Agreement
from August&nbsp;31, 2010 to August&nbsp;31, 2011. The Amendment also modified the borrowing rate of the Credit Agreement and borrowings now bear interest at the London Interbank Offered Rate
("LIBOR") plus 100 to 225 basis points based on certain financial measurements. In March 2008, a second amendment to the Credit Agreement modified the borrowing rate to LIBOR plus 100 to 237.5 basis
points based on certain financial measurements. There were no borrowings outstanding under this facility at May&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2. Financing Arrangements (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A summary of our recourse and non-recourse long-term debt is as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="70%" ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=5 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>May&nbsp;31,</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="1%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="70%" ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2008</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=43,EFW="2186742",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=551156,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK116:[08ZCE1.08ZCE77601]EA77601A.;10',USER='DBEMBEN',CD='11-JUL-2008;04:38' -->
<A NAME="page_ea77601_1_43"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2. Financing Arrangements (Continued) </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Recourse debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008, we retired $13,000 of our 8.39% notes due May&nbsp;15, 2011 for $12,578. The gain from this transaction was $422 and
is recorded in gain (loss) from extinguishment of debt on the consolidated statements of operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the third quarter of fiscal 2008, the holders of $16,355 of 2.875% convertible notes redeemed their notes for 880,000&nbsp;shares of our common stock. As a result of the
redemption, common stock increased $880 and capital surplus increased $15,284. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
February 2008, we completed the sale of $250,000&nbsp;of convertible notes, consisting of $137,500 aggregate principal amount of 1.625% convertible senior notes due 2014 and
$112,500&nbsp;aggregate principal amount of 2.25% convertible senior notes due 2016 (together, the "Notes") in a private offering to qualified institutional buyers pursuant to Rule&nbsp;144A
under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended. Interest under the Notes is payable semiannually on March&nbsp;1 and September&nbsp;1, beginning September&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holders
may convert their Notes based on a conversion rate of 28.1116&nbsp;shares of our common stock per $1,000 principal amount of Notes, which is equivalent to an initial conversion
price of $35.57 per share, only under the following circumstances: (i)&nbsp;during any calendar quarter beginning after March&nbsp;31, 2008 (and only during such calendar quarter) if, as of the
last day of the preceding calendar quarter, the closing price of our common stock for at least 20 trading days in a period of 30 consecutive trading days ending on the last trading day of such
preceding calendar quarter is more than 130% of the applicable conversion price per share of common stock on the last day of such preceding calendar quarter; (ii)&nbsp;during the five business day
period after any five consecutive trading day period in which the trading price per $1,000 principal amount of notes of the applicable series for each day of that period was less than 98% of the
product of the closing price of our common stock and the then applicable conversion rate; (iii)&nbsp;if a designated event or similar change of control transaction occurs; (iv)&nbsp;upon specified
corporate transactions; or (v)&nbsp;beginning on February&nbsp;1, 2014, in the case of the 2014 notes, or February&nbsp;1, 2016, in the case of the 2016 notes, and ending at the close of
business on the business day immediately preceding the applicable maturity date. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon
conversion, a holder of the Notes will receive, in lieu of common stock, an amount in cash equal to the lesser of (i)&nbsp;$1,000 and (ii)&nbsp;the conversion value of a number
of shares of our common stock equal to the conversion rate. If the conversion value exceeds the principal amount, we will also deliver at our election, cash or common stock or a combination thereof
having a value equal to such excess amount. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Notes are senior, unsecured obligations and rank equal in right of payment with all of our existing and future unsecured and unsubordinated expenses. Costs associated with this
transaction of
approximately $6,028 are being amortized on a pro-rata basis over a six- and eight-year period. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with the issuance of the Notes, we entered into convertible note hedge transactions, (note hedges) with respect to our common stock with Merrill Lynch Financial
Markets,&nbsp;Inc. (hedge provider). The note hedges are exercisable solely in connection with any conversion of the Notes and provide for us to receive shares of our common stock from the hedge
provider equal to the number of shares issuable to the holders of the Notes upon conversion. We paid $69,676 for the note hedges. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, we entered into separate warrant transactions with Merrill Lynch Financial Markets,&nbsp;Inc. whereby we issued warrants to purchase 7,028,000&nbsp;shares of our common
stock at an exercise price of $48.83 per share. We received $40,114 from the sale of these warrants. The convertible note hedges and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=44,EFW="2186742",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=292783,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK116:[08ZCE1.08ZCE77601]EA77601A.;10',USER='DBEMBEN',CD='11-JUL-2008;04:38' -->
<A NAME="page_ea77601_1_44"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2. Financing Arrangements (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>warrant
transactions are intended to reduce potential dilution to our common stock upon future conversion of the Notes and generally have the effect of increasing the conversion price of the Notes to
approximately $48.83 per share. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
proceeds from the Notes transaction after paying expenses were approximately $214,410 and were used to repay the balance outstanding under our unsecured revolving credit facility, to
pay for the net cost of the note hedges and warrant transactions and for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
February&nbsp;1, 2006, we completed the sale of $150,000 principal amount of convertible senior notes. The notes are due on February&nbsp;1, 2026 unless earlier redeemed,
repurchased or converted, and bear interest at 1.75% payable semiannually on February&nbsp;1 and August&nbsp;1. Costs associated with this transaction of approximately $4,875 are being amortized
over a seven-year period. Net proceeds from this transaction were $145,125 and were used in part to repurchase $25,000 of accounts receivable which had been sold under our former accounts
receivable securitization facility, to repay $25,000 outstanding under our secured revolving credit facility and to purchase for $11,232 aviation equipment which was subject to an operating lease. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
holder may convert the notes into shares of common stock based on a conversion rate of 33.9789&nbsp;shares per $1,000 principal amount of notes, which is equivalent to an initial
conversion price of approximately $29.43 per share, under the following circumstances: (i)&nbsp;during any calendar quarter beginning after March&nbsp;31, 2006 (and only during such calendar
quarter), if, as of the last day of the preceding calendar quarter, the closing price of our common stock for at least 20 trading days in a period of 30 consecutive trading days ending on the last
trading day of such preceding calendar quarter is more than 120% of the applicable conversion price per share of common stock on the last day of such preceding calendar quarter; (ii)&nbsp;during the
five business day period after any five consecutive trading day period in which the "trading price" per $1,000 principal amount of notes for each day of that period was less than 98% of the product of
the closing price of our common stock and the then
applicable conversion rate; (iii)&nbsp;upon a redemption notice; (iv)&nbsp;if a designated event or similar change of control transaction occurs; (v)&nbsp;upon specified corporate transactions;
or (vi)&nbsp;during the ten trading day period ending at the close of business on the business day immediately preceding the stated maturity date on the notes. Upon conversion, we will have the
right to deliver, in lieu of shares of our common stock, cash or a combination of cash and shares of common stock, at our option, in an amount per note equal to the applicable conversion rate
multiplied by the applicable stock price. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
may redeem for cash all or a portion of the notes at any time on or after February&nbsp;6, 2013 at specified redemption prices. Holders of the notes have the right to require us to
purchase for cash all or any portion of the notes on February&nbsp;1, 2013, 2016 and 2021 at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the notes plus accrued interest and unpaid interest, if
any, to the purchase date. The notes are senior, unsecured obligations and rank equal in right of payment with all other unsecured and unsubordinated indebtedness. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
mortgage loan due August&nbsp;1, 2015 is secured by our Wood Dale, Illinois facility. At May&nbsp;31, 2008, the net book value of our Wood Dale, Illinois facility is $14,427. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with the acquisition of Avborne, we assumed a $25,000 industrial revenue bond secured by maintenance hangars located at Miami International Airport. The industrial revenue
bond matures on August&nbsp;1, 2018 and has a variable interest rate. The interest rate at May&nbsp;31, 2008 was 1.68%. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=45,EFW="2186742",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=151398,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK116:[08ZCE1.08ZCE77601]EA77601A.;10',USER='DBEMBEN',CD='11-JUL-2008;04:38' -->
<A NAME="page_ea77601_1_45"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2. Financing Arrangements (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are subject to a number of covenants under our financing arrangements, including restrictions which relate to the payment of cash dividends, maintenance of minimum net working capital
and tangible net worth levels, fixed charge coverage ratio, sales of assets, additional financing, purchase of our shares and other matters. We are in compliance with all financial covenants under our
financing arrangements. The aggregate amount of long-term recourse debt maturing during each of the next five fiscal years is $200 in 2009, $200 in 2010, $42,108 in 2011, $0 in 2012 and $0
in 2013. Our long-term recourse debt was estimated to have a fair value of approximately $417,000 at May&nbsp;31, 2008. The fair value was determined using available market information. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Non-recourse debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the third quarter of fiscal 2008, we retired non-recourse debt that was secured by an aircraft which was sold during the third quarter of
fiscal 2008. The outstanding principal amount for this non-recourse debt was $19,748 and was retired for $20,375. The net loss from this
transaction was $627 and is recorded in gain (loss) on extinguishment of debt on the consolidated statement of operations </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;31, 2008, our total non-recourse debt balance is $39,402 and is secured by four aircraft with a net book value of $56,949. The aggregate amount of
long-term non-recourse debt maturing during each of the next five fiscal years is $20,212 in 2009, $2,462 in 2010, $2,658 in 2011, $2,860 in 2012 and $9,274 in 2013. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>3. Stock-Based Compensation  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We provide stock-based awards under the AAR CORP. Stock Benefit Plan ("Stock Benefit Plan") which has been approved by our stockholders. Under this plan, we are
authorized to issue stock options to employees and non-employee directors that allow the grant recipients to purchase shares of common stock at a price not less than the fair market value
of the common stock on the date of grant. Generally, stock options awarded under the plan expire ten years from the date of grant and are exercisable in either four or five equal annual increments
commencing one year after the date of grant. We issue new common stock upon the exercise of stock options. In addition to stock options, the Stock Benefit Plan also provides for the issuance of
restricted stock awards and performance-based restricted stock awards, as well as for the granting of stock appreciation units; however, to date, no stock appreciation units have been granted. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restricted
stock grants are designed, among other things, to align employee interests with the interests of stockholders and to encourage the recipient to build a career with the
Company. Restricted stock typically vests over periods of three to ten years from date of grant. Restricted stock grants may be performance-based with vesting to occur over periods of one to ten years
after the grant is earned. All restricted stock carries full dividend and voting rights, regardless of whether it has vested. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Typically,
stock options and restricted stock are subject to forfeiture prior to vesting if the employee terminates employment for any reason other than death, retirement or disability
or if we terminate employment for cause. A total of 5,237,000&nbsp;shares have been granted under the Stock Benefit Plan since its inception, and as of May&nbsp;31, 2008, awards representing
3,696,000&nbsp;shares were available for future grant under the Stock Benefit Plan. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->


 </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts)  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>3. Stock-Based Compensation (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
June&nbsp;1, 2006, we adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R), "Share-based Payment," using the modified prospective method of transition. Under SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R), compensation
expense is recognized for stock option grants made after May&nbsp;31, 2006 and for the unvested portion of outstanding stock options that were granted prior to the adoption of SFAS
No.&nbsp;123(R). Compensation cost is measured based on the grant date fair value of the award and recognized on a straight line basis over the vesting period. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior
to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R), we accounted for stock-based compensation in accordance with Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;25 ("APB&nbsp;25"),
"Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees," and SFAS No.&nbsp;123, "Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation". Under APB&nbsp;25, no compensation expense was recognized for stock option grants, and
accordingly share-based compensation related to stock options granted prior to June&nbsp;1, 2006 was included as pro forma disclosure in the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Stock Options  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;11, 2006, our Board of Directors approved the acceleration of the vesting of all unvested stock options. As a result of this action, stock options
representing approximately 679,000&nbsp;shares that were scheduled to vest in fiscal 2007, 2008 and 2009 became fully exercisable effective May&nbsp;1, 2006. The accelerated vesting enabled us to
reduce the amount of compensation expense that would otherwise be required to be recognized in our consolidated statements of operations with respect to these options upon the adoption of SFAS
No.&nbsp;123(R). The aggregate expense that was eliminated as a result of the acceleration was approximately $1,800. The acceleration resulted in a non-cash, one-time
pre-tax stock compensation expense of $362 in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
fiscal 2008 and fiscal 2007, we granted stock options representing 88,000&nbsp;shares and 100,000&nbsp;shares, respectively. No stock options were granted during fiscal 2006
other than reload options,
which resulted from the exercise of original stock options granted in prior years. Effective May&nbsp;1, 2006, the reload provision was eliminated from substantially all outstanding stock option
arrangements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
weighted average fair value of stock options granted during fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006 was $13.46, $11.93 and $3.71, respectively. The fair value of each stock option grant was
estimated on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option pricing model with the following assumptions: </FONT></P>

dividend yield represents our anticipated cash dividends over the expected option term. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The total fair value of stock options that vested during fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006 was $227, $0 and $1,628, respectively. The total intrinsic value of stock
options exercised during fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006 was $12,627, $13,582 and $17,148, respectively. The aggregate intrinsic value of options outstanding as of May&nbsp;31, 2008 was $4,080. The tax
benefit realized from stock options exercised during fiscal 2008 and 2007 was $4,657 and $4,345, respectively. As of May&nbsp;31, 2008, we had $1,672 of unrecognized compensation expense related to
stock options that will be amortized over an average period of five years. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>3. Stock-Based Compensation (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

following table provides additional information regarding stock options outstanding as of May&nbsp;31, 2008 (shares in thousands): </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Restricted Stock  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We provide executives and other key employees an opportunity to be awarded performance-based restricted stock. The award is contingent upon the achievement of
certain performance objectives, including net income and return on capital, or the Company's stock price achieving a certain level over a period of time. After the shares are granted, the restrictions
are released over a three to seven year period. During fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006, we granted 35,000, 459,000 and 438,000 restricted shares, respectively, under this program. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the performance-based restricted stock awards, we also granted a total of 20,000 restricted shares to members of the Board of Directors during fiscal 2008. These shares
vest over a three-year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair value of restricted shares is the market value of our common stock on the date of grant. Amortization expense related to all restricted shares during fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006
was $5,943, $3,458 and $3,690 respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restricted
share activity during the fiscal year ended May&nbsp;31, 2008 is as follows (shares in thousands): </FONT></P>

<A NAME="page_ec77601_1_49"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>3. Stock-Based Compensation (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>unearned
compensation related to restricted shares that will be amortized to expense over a weighted average period of 2.2&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Shareholders' Rights Plan  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant to a shareholder rights plan adopted in 2007, each outstanding share of our common stock carries with it a Right to purchase one share at a price of $140
per share. The Rights become exercisable (and separate from the shares) when certain specified events occur, including the acquisition of 15% or more of the common stock by a person or group (an
"Acquiring Person") or the commencement of a tender or exchange offer for 15% or more of the common stock. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the event that an Acquiring Person acquires 15% or more of the common stock, or if we are the surviving corporation in a merger involving an Acquiring Person or if the Acquiring
Person engages in certain types of self-dealing transactions, each Right entitles the holder to purchase for $140 per share (or the then-current exercise price), shares of our
common stock having a market value of $280 (or two times the exercise price), subject to certain exceptions. Similarly, if we are acquired in a merger or other business combination or 50% or more of
our assets or earning power is sold, each Right entitles the holder to purchase at the then-current exercise price that number of shares of common stock of the surviving corporation having
a market value of two times the exercise price. The Rights do not entitle the holder thereof to vote or to receive dividends. The Rights will expire on August&nbsp;6, 2017, and may be redeemed by us
for $.01 per Right under certain circumstances. The 2007 rights plan replaced a shareholder rights plan that expired on August&nbsp;6, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
June&nbsp;20, 2006 our Board of Directors authorized us to purchase up to 1,500,000&nbsp;shares of our common stock on the market. This action superseded our previous stock
repurchase plan which had remaining authorization to purchase 1,255,000&nbsp;shares. During fiscal 2008, we purchased 321,700&nbsp;shares of our common stock on the open market at an average price
of $29.61. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The deferred tax provision results primarily from differences between financial reporting and taxable income arising from inventory and depreciation. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income
tax payable at May 31, 2008 and 2007 was $14,523 and $2,101, respectively, and is included in accrued liabilities on the consolidated balance sheet. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
provision for income taxes on continuing operations differs from the amount computed by applying the U.S. federal statutory income tax rate of 35% for fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006 to
income before taxes, for the following reasons: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In October of 2004, the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 (the "Act") was signed into law and included a number of Federal income tax reforms, including the
phase-out of tax benefits on earnings from export sales. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>4. Income Taxes (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of May&nbsp;31, 2008, we have determined that the realization of our deferred tax assets is more likely than not, and that a valuation allowance is not
required based upon our history of operating earnings, the nature of certain of our deferred tax assets, our expectations for continued future earnings and the scheduled reversal of deferred tax
liabilities, primarily related to depreciation. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>5. Earnings Per Share  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The computation of basic earnings per share is based on the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during each period. The computation of diluted
earnings per share is based on the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period plus, when their effect is dilutive, incremental shares consisting of shares subject to stock
options, shares issuable upon vesting of restricted stock awards and shares to be issued upon conversion of convertible debt. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
the provisions of Emerging Issues Task Force Issue No.&nbsp;04-08, "The Effect of Contingently Convertible Instruments on Diluted Earnings per Share" ("EITF
No.&nbsp;04-08"), we are required to use the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>51</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=52,EFW="2186742",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=1011390,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK116:[08ZCE1.08ZCE77601]EE77601A.;14',USER='DBEMBEN',CD='11-JUL-2008;04:38' -->
<A NAME="page_ee77601_1_52"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>5. Earnings Per Share (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>"if
converted" method set forth in SFAS No.&nbsp;128, "Earnings Per Share," in calculating the diluted earnings per share effect of the assumed conversion of our contingently convertible debt issued
in fiscal 2006 because the principal for that issuance can be settled in stock, cash or a combination thereof. Under the "if converted" method, the after-tax effect of interest expense
related to the convertible securities is added back to net income, and the convertible debt is assumed to have been converted into common shares at the beginning of the period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table provides a reconciliation of the computations of basic and diluted earnings per share information for each of the years in the three-year period ended
May&nbsp;31, 2008 (shares in thousands). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At May&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively, options to purchase 78,000, 31,000 and 1,200,000&nbsp;shares of common stock were
outstanding, but were not included in the computation of diluted earnings per share, because the exercise price of these options was greater than the average market price of the common shares. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=53,EFW="2186742",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=216787,FOLIO='52',FILE='DISK116:[08ZCE1.08ZCE77601]EE77601A.;14',USER='DBEMBEN',CD='11-JUL-2008;04:38' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_eg77601_1_53"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->


 </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts)  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>6. Employee Benefit Plans  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have defined contribution and defined benefit plans covering substantially all full-time domestic employees and certain employees in The
Netherlands. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Defined Benefit Plans  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to January&nbsp;1, 2000, the pension plan for domestic salaried and non-union hourly employees had a benefit formula based primarily on years
of service and compensation. Effective January&nbsp;1, 2000, we converted our defined benefit plan for substantially all domestic salaried and certain hourly employees to a cash balance pension
plan. Under the cash balance pension plan, the retirement benefit is expressed as a dollar amount in an account that grows with annual pay-based credits and interest on the account
balance. The interest crediting rate under our cash balance plan is determined quarterly and is equal to 100% of the average 30-year treasury rate for the second month preceding the
applicable quarter published by the Internal Revenue Service. The average interest crediting rate under our cash balance plan for the fiscal year ended May&nbsp;31, 2008 was 4.90%. Effective
June&nbsp;1, 2005, the existing cash balance plan was frozen and the annual pay-based credits were discontinued. Also effective June&nbsp;1, 2005, the defined contribution plan was
modified to include increased employer contributions and an enhanced profit sharing formula. Defined pension benefits for certain union hourly employees are based primarily on a fixed amount per year
of service. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
foreign operations of domestic subsidiaries also have a defined pension plan. Benefit formulas are based generally on years of service and compensation. It is the policy of these
subsidiaries to fund at least the minimum amounts required by local laws and regulations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
provide eligible outside directors with benefits upon retirement on or after age 65 provided they have completed at least five years of service as a director. Benefits are paid
quarterly in cash equal to 25% of the annual retainer fee payable to active outside directors. Payment of benefits commence upon retirement and continues for a period equal to the total number of
years of the retired director's service up to a maximum of ten years, or death, whichever occurs first. In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2001, we terminated the plan for any new members of the Board of
Directors elected after May&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
also provide supplemental pension benefits for certain executives and key employees to supplement benefits provided by the cash balance plan. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
May&nbsp;31, 2007, we adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;158, "Employers' Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans". SFAS No.&nbsp;158
requires employers to recognize the overfunded or underfunded status of a defined benefit pension or other postretirement plan as an asset or liability in its statement of financial position,
recognize changes in that funded status in the year in which the changes occur through comprehensive income and measure a plan's assets and its obligations that determine its funded status as of the
end of the employer's fiscal year. We have historically measured the plan assets and liabilities as of our balance sheet date. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>53</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;158, a minimum pension liability adjustment was required when the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits
exceeded plan assets and accrued pension
liabilities. During fiscal 2007, we reduced the minimum pension liability by $3,104, and $1,921, net of tax, was reported as a component of comprehensive income. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>6. Employee Benefit Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Assumptions  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The assumptions used in accounting for the Company's plans are estimates of factors including, among other things, the amount and timing of future benefit
payments. The following table presents the key assumptions used in the measurement of the Company's benefit obligations: </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>6.50</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>6.50</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>6.50</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rate was determined by projecting the plan's expected future benefit payments as defined for the projected benefit obligation, discounting those
expected payments using a theoretical zero-coupon spot yield curve derived from a universe of high-quality bonds as of the measurement date, and solving for the single
equivalent discount rate that resulted in the same projected benefit obligation. Constraints were applied with respect to callability and credit quality. In addition, 3% of the bonds were deemed
outliers due to questionable pricing information and consequently were excluded from consideration. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>56</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>6. Employee Benefit Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The assets of U.S pension plans are invested in compliance with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA). The investment goals are to provide a
total return that, over the long term, optimizes the long-term return on plan assets at an acceptable risk, and to maintain a broad diversification across asset classes and among
investment managers. Direct investments in our securities and the use of derivatives for the purpose of speculation are not permitted. The assets of the U.S. pension plans are invested primarily in
equity and fixed income mutual funds, individual common stocks and investments in fund-of funds hedge funds. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
assets of the non-domestic plan are invested in compliance with local laws and regulations and are comprised of insurance contracts and equity and fixed income mutual
funds. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To
develop our expected long-term rate of return assumption on domestic plans, we use long-term historical return information for our targeted asset mix and
current market conditions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cash Flow  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our contribution policy for the domestic plans is to contribute annually, at a minimum, an amount which is deductible for federal income tax purposes and that is
sufficient to meet actuarially computed pension benefits. We anticipate contributing $2,000 to $4,000 during fiscal 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>6. Employee Benefit Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We provide health and life insurance benefits for certain eligible retirees. The postretirement plans are unfunded and in fiscal 1995, we completed termination of
postretirement health and life insurance benefits attributable to future services of collective bargaining and other domestic employees. The unfunded projected benefit obligation for this plan was
$1,427 and $1,370 as of May&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, respectively. We have omitted substantially all of the required disclosures related to this plan because the plan is not material to our
consolidated financial position or results of operations. Effective May&nbsp;31, 2007, we adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;158 for this plan resulting in an increase to accumulated
comprehensive loss of $465, net of tax. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Defined Contribution Plan  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The defined contribution plan is a profit sharing plan which is intended to qualify as a 401(k) plan under the Internal Revenue Code. Under the plan, employees
may contribute up to 75% of their pretax compensation, subject to applicable regulatory limits. We may make matching contributions up to 5% of compensation as well as discretionary profit sharing
contributions. Company contributions vest on a pro-rata basis during the first three years of employment. We also provide supplemental profit sharing benefits for certain executives and
key employees to supplement the benefits provided by the defined contribution plan. Expense charged to results of operations for Company matching contributions, including profit sharing contributions,
was $8,666 in fiscal 2008, $5,501 in fiscal 2007 and $4,216 in fiscal 2006 for these plans. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>7. Acquisitions  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;12, 2007, we acquired substantially all of the assets of Reebaire Aircraft,&nbsp;Inc. ("Reebaire"), a regional airframe maintenance, repair
and overhaul facility located in Hot Springs, Arkansas. This acquisition increases our regional maintenance, repair and overhaul capacity in North America. The purchase price was $11,800 and was paid
in cash. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;2, 2007, we acquired Brown International Corporation ("Brown"), a privately held defense contractor that provides engineering, design, manufacturing and systems
integration services. Brown operates as part of our Structures and Systems segment. The purchase price was approximately $26,700 and was paid in cash. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>58</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>(1,500</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On December&nbsp;3, 2007, we acquired Summa Technology,&nbsp;Inc. ("Summa"), a leading provider of high-end sub-systems and precision
machining, fabrication, welding and engineering services. Summa operates as part of our Structures and Systems segment. The purchase price was approximately $71,000 and was paid in cash. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
March&nbsp;5, 2008, we acquired Avborne Heavy Maintenance,&nbsp;Inc. ("Avborne") and a related entity. Avborne is an independent provider of aircraft heavy maintenance checks,
modifications, installations
and painting services to commercial airlines, international cargo carriers and major aircraft leasing companies. The purchase price was approximately $40,000 and included a cash payment of $15,000 and
the assumption of a $25,000 industrial revenue bond. Avborne operates as part of our Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have made a preliminary purchase price allocation for the Summa and Avborne acquisitions and are in the process of obtaining final valuations for the acquired net assets. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following unaudited pro forma information is provided for acquisitions assuming the Brown, Summa and Avborne acquisitions occurred as of the beginning of fiscal year 2006: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>8. Aircraft Joint Ventures  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our aircraft joint ventures represent investments in limited liability companies that are accounted for under the equity method of accounting. Our membership
interest in each of these limited liability companies is 50% and the primary business of these companies is the acquisition, ownership, lease and disposition of certain commercial aircraft. Aircraft
are purchased with cash contributions by the members of the companies and debt financing provided to the limited liability companies on a limited recourse basis. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>59</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_ei77601_1_60"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>8. Aircraft Joint Ventures (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Twenty-nine
aircraft were held in the joint ventures at May&nbsp;31, 2008. Under the terms of servicing agreements with certain of the limited liability companies, we provide
administrative services and technical advisory services, including aircraft evaluations, oversight and logistical support of the maintenance process and records management. We also provide remarketing
services with respect to the divestiture of aircraft by the limited liability companies. During fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006, we were paid $232, $1,115 and $574, respectively, for such services. The
income tax benefit or expense related to the operations of the ventures is recorded by the member companies. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Distributions
from joint ventures are classified as operating or investing activities in the consolidated statements of cash flows based upon an evaluation of the specific facts and
circumstances of each distribution. </FONT></P>

financial information for these limited liability companies is as follows: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the second quarter of fiscal 2008, an aircraft held by a joint venture, which was previously consolidated because we were the primary beneficiary of the
joint venture, was sold. The minority interest related to the gain on the sale was approximately $2,400 and is recorded as an increase to cost of sales in the consolidated statement of operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>9. Equipment on Long-Term Lease  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2005, we entered into a series of ten-year agreements with Mesa to provide supply chain services for their fleet of CRJ&nbsp;700/900,
ERJ&nbsp;145 and CRJ&nbsp;200 regional jets. As part of the agreements, we purchased from the customer approximately $58,400 of equipment to support the program. The equipment is included in
equipment on long-term lease on the consolidated balance sheet and is being depreciated on a straight-line basis over 10&nbsp;years to a 30% residual value. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>10. Commitments and Contingencies  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;3, 2003, we entered into a sale-leaseback transaction whereby the Company sold and leased back a facility located in Garden City,
New York. The lease is classified as an operating lease in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;13 "Accounting for Leases". Net proceeds from the sale of the facility were $13,991 and the cost and related
accumulated depreciation of the facility of $9,472 and $4,595, respectively, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>60</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=61,EFW="2186742",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=584542,FOLIO='60',FILE='DISK116:[08ZCE1.08ZCE77601]EI77601A.;16',USER='DBEMBEN',CD='11-JUL-2008;04:38' -->
<A NAME="page_ei77601_1_61"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>10. Commitments and Contingencies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>were
removed from the consolidated balance sheet. The gain realized on the sale of $9,114 has been deferred and is being amortized over the 20-year lease term in accordance with SFAS
No.&nbsp;13. The unamortized balance of the deferred gain as of May&nbsp;31, 2008 is $7,071 and is included in other liabilities and deferred income on the consolidated balance sheet. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the Garden City lease, we lease other facilities and equipment as well as aviation equipment under agreements that are classified as operating leases that expire at
various dates through 2034. Under the terms of one of the facility lease agreements, we are entitled to receive rent credits as we increase the space we occupy. During fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006, we
received $1,000, $700 and $1,700, respectively, of such rent credits and in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;13, we are treating the rent credits as lease incentives, which are being amortized over the
term of the lease. Future minimum payments under all operating leases at May&nbsp;31, 2008 are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="80%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="58%" ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=5 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Future Minimum Payments</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="58%" ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Year<BR> </B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Facilities<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2008, we completed a sale-leaseback transaction with a financial institution to finance an aircraft under a capital lease.
Proceeds were approximately $12,880. We are sub-leasing the aircraft under an operating lease with a remaining period of four years. The gross asset balance and accumulated depreciation of
this aircraft as of May&nbsp;31, 2008 is $15,093 and $641, respectively and is included in equipment on long-term lease on the consolidated balance sheet. Future minimum payments and
sub-lease rentals under capitalized leases are as follows: </FONT></P>

<A NAME="page_ei77601_1_62"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>10. Commitments and Contingencies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We routinely issue letters of credit and performance bonds in the ordinary course of our business. These instruments are typically issued in conjunction with
insurance contracts or other business requirements. The total of these instruments outstanding at May&nbsp;31, 2008 was approximately $18,032. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are involved in various claims and legal actions, including environmental matters, arising in the ordinary course of business (see Item&nbsp;3 Legal Proceedings). In the opinion of
management, the ultimate disposition of these matters will not have a material adverse effect on our consolidated financial condition or results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>11. Discontinued Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the third quarter of fiscal 2007, we decided to exit our non-core industrial turbine business based in Frankfort, New York. Net assets of the
business were approximately $4,600 at May&nbsp;31, 2008 and consisted of $2,300 of accounts receivable, $800 of inventory, $1,800 of net property, plant and equipment and $300 of accounts payable. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues
and pre-tax operating loss for fiscal years 2008, 2007 and 2006 for the discontinued operations are summarized as follows: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>12. Gain on Sale of Product Line  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2007, we sold substantially all assets, subject to certain liabilities, of a product line within our Structures and Systems
segment. Proceeds from the sale were $6,567 and the net carrying value of the assets sold was $1,209, resulting in a gain on sale of product line of $5,358. The gain on this transaction has been
classified as a component of operating income in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;144, "Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets." </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>13. Impairment Charges  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2007, we recorded an impairment charge related to certain engine parts in the amount of $4,750. These parts were acquired prior
to September&nbsp;11, 2001. The fiscal 2007 impairment charge was triggered by our decision to pursue the liquidation of this inventory. We made the decision to recognize the impairment due to the
impact of persistently high fuel costs and reduced demand for these parts, as well as to better align human and physical resources with higher potential opportunities in the rapidly growing Aviation
Supply Chain segment. We had previously recorded impairment charges of $5,360 during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2003 and $75,900 during the second quarter of fiscal 2002 related to engine and
airframe parts and whole engines. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>62</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Proceeds from sales of impaired inventory and engines for the twelve-month periods ended May&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007, and 2006 were $3,200, $3,800 and $7,300,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Other Impairment and Gain on Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2007, we restructured the lease and non-recourse debt on a wholly-owned wide-body aircraft. This
aircraft was originally purchased prior to September&nbsp;11, 2001. As a result of the restructuring of the lease and debt, we recorded a $2,927 gain on extinguishment of debt. Further, we decided
to offer this aircraft for sale and recorded a $2,902 impairment charge to reduce the carrying value of the aircraft to its estimated net realizable value. This aircraft was sold during the third
quarter of fiscal 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>14. Other Noncurrent Assets  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At May&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, other noncurrent assets consisted of the following: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Program Development Costs  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2005, we announced that our Cargo Systems business was selected to provide cargo handling systems for the new A400M cargo aircraft. We are a subcontractor
to PFW on this Airbus program. Our portion of the revenue from this program is expected to exceed $300,000 through fiscal 2015, based on sales projections of the A400M. As of May&nbsp;31, 2008, we
have incurred approximately $43,000 of costs associated with the engineering and development of the cargo system and have capitalized these costs in accordance with SOP&nbsp;81-1
"Accounting for Performance of Construction&#151;Type and Certain Production&#151;Type Contracts." Sales and related cost of sales will be recognized on the units of delivery method. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>63</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ek77601_1_64"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->


 </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts)  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>15. Business Segment Information  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Segment Reporting  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We report our activities in four business segments: Aviation Supply Chain; Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul; Structures and Systems; and Aircraft Sales and
Leasing. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales
in the Aviation Supply Chain segment are derived from the sale and lease of a wide variety of new, overhauled and repaired engine and airframe parts and components to the
commercial aviation and defense markets, as well as the repair and overhaul of a wide range of commercial and military aircraft parts and components. We also offer customized programs for inventory
supply and management and performance-based logistics. Sales also include the sale and lease of commercial jet engines. Cost of sales consists principally of the cost of product (primarily aircraft
and engine parts), direct labor and overhead (primarily indirect labor, facility cost and insurance). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales
in the Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul segment are principally derived from aircraft maintenance and storage and the repair and overhaul of landing gear. Cost of sales consists
principally of the cost of product (primarily replacement aircraft parts), direct labor and overhead. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales
in the Structures and Systems segment are derived from the engineering, design and manufacture of containers, pallets and shelters used to support the U.S. military's tactical
deployment requirements, complex machined and fabricated parts, components and sub-systems for various aerospace and defense programs and other applications, in-plane cargo
loading and handling systems for commercial and military applications and composite products for aviation and industrial use. Cost of sales consists principally of the cost of product, direct labor
and overhead. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales
in the Aircraft Sales and Leasing segment are derived from the sale and lease of commercial aircraft and technical and advisory services. Cost of sales consists principally of the
cost of product (aircraft), labor and the cost of lease revenue (primarily depreciation and insurance). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
accounting policies for the segments are the same as those described in Note&nbsp;1. Our chief operating decision making officer (Chief Executive Officer) evaluates performance
based on the reportable segments and utilizes gross profit as a primary profitability measure. The expenses and assets related to corporate activities are not allocated to the segments. Our reportable
segments are aligned principally around differences in products and services. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
profit is calculated by subtracting cost of sales from sales. Selected financial information for each reportable segment is as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<A NAME="page_ek77601_1_65"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>AAR CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>15. Business Segment Information (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<!-- end of table folio -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=8 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><BR>
For the Year Ended May&nbsp;31,</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2008</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2007</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2006</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales to unaffiliated customers in foreign countries, the majority of which are located in Europe, the Middle East, Canada, Mexico, South America and Asia
(including sales through foreign sales offices of domestic subsidiaries), were approximately $330,132 (23.7% of total sales), $291,892 (27.5% of total sales) and $237,997 (26.9% of total sales) in
fiscal 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. </FONT></P>
